data.title: Ant build fails to compile RenderSupport
data.body:
As of 7b604d3, if I run the Ant build in starling/build/ant using the latest Flex 4.6, I get the following error:   

```
[compc] Loading configuration file /Users/charlie/dev/flex4/frameworks/flex-config.xml
[compc] /Users/charlie/dev/Starling-Framework/starling/src/starling/core/RenderSupport.as(16): col: 27 Error: Definition starling.events:Event could not be found.
[compc] 
[compc]     import starling.events.Event;
[compc]                           ^
[compc]
```

That import isn't used, and if I remove it from RenderSupport, the compile succeeds. It seems like it should work regardless, but I've seen weirder behavior from the ActionScript compiler.

data.title: Removing sibling in Event.REMOVED_FROM_STAGE listener causes removal of wrong child
Custom native cursors are disabled when mousing over a Button
Optimization for getLocation() on Touch object
data.body:
Two options. Depends on the behavior of Matrix's transformPoint():

1) If the Matrix modifies the point that is passed into transformPoint(), then I suggest new function signature:

```
public function getLocation( space:DisplayObject, result:Point = null ):Point
```

It will allow us to reuse the same Point object, if desired, and save on object allocation.

2) If a new Point is created when transformPoint() is called, then we're at the mercy of the runtime. We can still make it work a little better, though. Currently, a new Point is created every time before we pass it to transformPoint(). Instead, a static sHelperPoint could be added. That should help a little so only one Point is created instead of two.

data.title: QuadBatch as display object: memory leak without dispose()
data.body:
This event listener is added in the constructor for QuadBatch:

```
Starling.current.addEventListener(Event.CONTEXT3D_CREATE, onContextCreated);
```

Is there a way to add this listener in an Event.ADDED_TO_STAGE listener instead (and removed in Event.REMOVED_FROM_STAGE)? The reason I ask is because if someone forgets to call dispose() on the QuadBatch when they're done with it, it will cause a memory leak because Starling will keep a reference to the listener.

I understand that QuadBatch isn't always on the display list, but maybe there's a way to select the behavior based on how a particular QuadBatch is being used.

data.title: Starling's event bubbling is not consistent with Flash's system following display list mutation
data.body:
When bubbling display events, Starling evaluates the next target up the display tree with each bubble dispatch. This means that any children added during the dispatch will also get the event. Calling removeChild() has the potential to stop the event chain entirely (Which is pretty annoying when doing UI events - e.g. hiding windows).

In traditional Flash: the objects that will receive the bubbled event are decided at dispatch time. Any changes to the display tree during the dispatches will have no effect on the objects receiving the event. As Starling's goal is to be familiar to Flash developers I think this behavior should probably be made to be consistent.

This patch adjusts the bubbling system to calculate the list on the first dispatch - in keeping with Flash's normal behavior.

data.title: Expose mData as a getter on ConcreteTexture?
data.body:
It would be nice to get access to mData stored in ConcreteTexture for certain potential use cases.
I realize maybe you don't want to expose it if handle lost context is needed but here is why it might be nice to expose:

Let's say that you want to possibly use some form of pixel hit detection. Normally the suggestion is to store and keep a reference to the original bitmapData.  That is reasonable, but on many platforms we also might have to turn on handleLostContext which means Starling concrete textures will also end up keeping around a reference to the source bitmap data.

It would be great if we know we are using handleLostContext = true to just rely and use Starling's existing reference of the bitmapData in ConcreteTexture if we could get at it with a getter.

However, you might initially think that there is no difference to externally keeping a reference to the bitmapData since Starling is only just going to keep a reference to that same original bitmapData and so there is no memory cost savings, but in general this might not be the case.
Inside Texture, if the incoming bitmapData is not a POT texture, Starling internally creates a new BitmapData instance and will use this new POT sized bitmapData as its reference.
We would then be keeping around two copies of bitmapData instances for any nonPOT data with handleLostContext = true.

If we could just always ask for the stored mData from Starling's ConcreteTexture we would only ever have one bitmapData instance per ConcreteTexture.

data.title: use more then one of Starling instance.
Added native filter support for Starling's TextField
data.body:
Most other native TF properties had a mapping but filters didn't. My understanding is that Starling will probably implement a filters system similar to native at some point anyway - but that will be applicable to all DOs. I think TF's can be an exception as they are already being rendered using native anyway (bitmap excluded), so I have added a 'nativeFilters' property accordingly.

This gives a nice way to quickly get the same effects we had during design time in the IDE - something that's often critical on mobile devices for readability anyway. Glow Filters and Drop Shadows in particular are great for readability.

Any applied filters that increase the size (i.e. Glow Filters) would still need room inside the TF to render - but as this also applies to specifying the text size anyway (autoScale aside) I don't think this is an issue.

data.title: Set image color to 0xffffff and the alpha will lost.
Starling.updateViewPort raises error when context got disposed
data.body:
Setting mStarling.viewPort when the stage resizes (by rotating the device) raises an error on Android:

Error: Error #3694: The object was disposed by an earlier call of dispose() on it.
    at flash.display3D::Context3D/configureBackBuffer()
    at starling.core::Starling/updateViewPort()[/Users/redge/Development/starling/starling/src/starling/core/Starling.as:257]
    at starling.core::Starling/set viewPort()[/Users/redge/Development/starling/starling/src/starling/core/Starling.as:537]
    at Test/onResize()[.../ViewPortBug/src/Test.as:27]
    at starling.events::EventDispatcher/dispatchEvent()[/Users/redge/Development/starling/starling/src/starling/events/EventDispatcher.as:109]
    at starling.display::DisplayObject/dispatchEvent()[/Users/redge/Development/starling/starling/src/starling/display/DisplayObject.as:328]
    at starling.core::Starling/onResize()[/Users/redge/Development/starling/starling/src/starling/core/Starling.as:398]

data.title: Should DisplayObjectContainer#root really be Stage?
data.body: Should DisplayObjectContainer#root really be Stage? There is stage getter already. Main Starling app class (the one you pass at Starling initialization) is expected, similar to native DisplayList architecture.

data.title: Bitmap Font error when last character is missing
data.body:
If the bitmap font is missing a character and this character happens to be the last character of the string, there will be an endless loop.

More information here:
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/bug-bitmap-font-missing-character

data.title: DisplayObjectContainer.broadcastEvent reduce object creation optimization
data.body:
Using the very latest code drop that implements the new event pooling (thanks!)
It now makes it extremely easy to watch the cumulated instances view in the profiler in FlashBuilder and not be distracted by lots of newly created instances (even ones that would get gc-ed)

What I just noticed in the latest code drop profiling in FB is that there is now only one particular cumulatively growing instance group when you watch an idle Starling app (an app that doesn't do anything when user interaction isn't occurring)

This is an evergrowing creation of Vector.<*> instances.

I have traced these to the DisplayObjectContainer.broadcastEvent method which creates a new vector of listeners on each call to broadcastEvent.  (and so when EnterFrameEvent is called there is still the creation of a new vector instance to hold the listeners on this and every broadcast.

Would it not be possible (in this current non-threaded environment, to have each DisplayObjectContainer keep an ivar broadcastListeners Vector (cant use a static helper because of nested triggering?) and only set its length to zero on each call of broadcastEvent to build up the listener set?

I just tested this locally and there would now be absolutely zero instance creation going on during an idle app (and not to mention a reduced set of object creation whenever broadcasting events)

Or is this not possible because a single container could trigger multiple event broadcasts nested and so would cause corruption of the broadcastListener vector?  Would it be possible to setup another pool of listener vectors for this to still allow reduced object creation here?

data.title: removeChild() / removeChildAt() should return the removed child
data.body: In traditional AS3 when you remove a child from it's container, the removed child is returned. It would be nice to have that happen in Starling as well.

data.title: Provide scale value to TextureAtlas for "more" Texture in GPU
getTransformationMatrix improved optimization check
Minor improvement for localToGlobal and globalToLocal ??
data.body:
Maybe I'm barking up the wrong tree, but looking at the current code for these functions it walks up the objects parents to root and concatenates each transform matrix at each step.
Isn't the result the same if instead you asked for the root() object and did a single call to getTransformationMatrix which interally has optimizations for certain child/parent conditions (and also walks parents)

Is there potentially less math in the alternative coding or is it minimal?

data.title: Tween.dispose() to remove Tween
Alpha doesn't apply when textfield in flattenned container
data.body:
Hi,

I have a textfield (using bitmapfont) inside a sprite, if I flatten the sprite, the textfield alpha is always 1.
I did try re-flatten (or even unflatten/flatten) but it did not work.
It easy to reproduce, just create a textfield, set the alpha to something, add it to a sprite, flatten the sprite, no more alpha!

Good luck,

Seb

data.title: Allow DelayedCall to trigger an indefinite amount of calls
data.body:
Hello!

I recently felt the need to use delayed calls that trigger an indefinite amount of time instead of a fixed amount.

To activate the indefinite behavior, all that's needed is to set the repeatCount property to 0. This mimics how Adobe's Timer class works.

I admit it's not a ground-breaking modification, but it helps keep code lean and it's a very useful behavior.

I've also included a stop() method to manually fire the REMOVE_FROM_JUGGLER event and a totalCalls property to keep track of how many times the DelayedCall has fired.

Hope you find it useful enough to include it!

data.title: TouchProcessor and errors on operations that require "user action, such as a mouse event or keypress event"
data.body:
And again touch-stuff implementation bothers me =)
As you should know there are several operations that require "user action, such as a mouse event or keypress event" in order to work, otherwise Error or SecurityError is thrown.
These two comes to my mind first (but there are more, right?)
http://help.adobe.com/en_US/FlashPlatform/reference/actionscript/3/flash/display/Stage.html#displayState
http://help.adobe.com/en_US/FlashPlatform/reference/actionscript/3/flash/net/FileReference.html#download()

As your TouchProcessor is essentially a "ticker" I see a problem... and don't see any workaround other then listening input on native stage + performing manual hittest. kinda ugly.

data.title: Juggler: potential memory leak when using purge method
data.body:
Hi,

I found a source of memory leaks.
If one use purge to clean up the juggler, the listener for Event.REMOVE_FROM_JUGGLER does not get removed and this results in preventing them from the garbage collection.

I fixed the issue locally by calling the "remove" method on each object within the "purge" function. Although this is not as efficient, this fixed the memory leaks.

Cheers.

data.title: Memory leak when computing displayObject's transformMatrix
data.body:
Hi,

While working on our game, we noticed some issue with object still in memory that shouldn't.
After a bit of profiling, we found the culprit:

In getTransformationMatrix of DisplayObject, you are using sAncestors Vector to hold the hierarchy of parents, but you are not emptying it afterwards. So all the hierarchy is still referenced from that object after the method complete.

I suggest setting the length to 0 line 220 and line 250.

Sebastien

data.title: deal with scaleMode...deal with scaleMode
MovieClip will stop at last frame
Add skewX and skewY to DisplayObject.
data.body:
This takes advantage of the fact that a rotation is a skew where both skewX and skewY angles are equal. A bit less memory is used, at the cost of not being able to conveniently both skew and rotate the same DisplayObject.

(Patched version!)
